comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: The Florence Griswold house, in Old Lyme, Connecticut, was built in 1817. It was designed by architect Samuel Belcher, in what is now called the the Late Georgian style (in England), or the Federal style (in the United States.) In 1841, it became the home of sea captain Robert Griswold. In the late 19th century, Captain Griswold's heirs, including his daughter Florence (1850-1937), began taking in boarders. Among these boarders were several artists, and by the 1910s, the Griswold boarding house, and its proprietor, had become the center of Old Lyme's thriving artist colony. The Griswold house has been the Florence Griswold Museum since 1947. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1975, and was declared a national historic Landmark in 1993. Florence Griswold Museum web site.
